question: As explained in the section on the properties of alcohol, what does alcohol look like in appearance?
llm_answer: The provided context does not describe the physical appearance of alcohol.

context.text: all over the country. You are too young to understand how this is done, but you each have something inside of you, by which you are sending messages almost every minute while you are awake. We will try to learn a little about its wonderful way of working. In your head is your brain. It is the part of you which thinks. As you would be very badly off if you could not think, the brain is your most precious part, and you have a strong box made of bone to keep it in. [Illustration: _Diagram of the nervous system._] We will call the brain the central telegraph office. Little white cords, called nerves, connect the brain with the rest of the body. A large cord called the spinal cord, lies safely in a bony case made by the spine, and many nerves branch off from this. If you put your finger on a hot stove, in an instant a message goes on the nerve telegraph to the brain. It tells that wise thinking part that your finger will burn, if it stays on the stove. In another instant, the brain sends back a message to the muscles that move that finger, saying: "Contract quickly, bend the joint, and take that poor finger away so that it will not be burned." You can hardly believe that there was time for all this sending of messages; for as soon as you felt the hot stove, you pulled your finger away. But you really could not have pulled it away, unless

NERVES. [Illustration: H]OW do the muscles know when to move? You have all seen the telegraph wires, by which messages are sent from one town to another, all over the country. You are too young to understand how this is done, but you each have something inside of you, by which you are sending

[Illustration: T]HE blood flows all through the body, carrying good food to every part. It also gathers up from every part the worn-out matter that can no longer be used. By the time it is ready to be sent back by the veins, the blood is no longer pure and red. It is dull and bluish in color, because it is full of impurities. If you look at the veins in your

are floating in the air, and so save their going to the lungs. You will get out of breath less quickly when running if you keep your mouth shut. DOES ALCOHOL DO ANY HARM TO THE LUNGS? The little air-cells of the lungs have very delicate muscular (m[)u]s'ku lar) walls. Every time we breathe, these walls have to move. The muscles of the chest must also move, as you can all notice in yourselves, as you breathe. All this muscular work, as well as that of the stomach and heart, is directed by the nerves. You have learned already what alcohol will do to muscles and nerves, so you are ready to answer for stomach, for heart, and for lungs. Is alcohol a help to them? REVIEW QUESTIONS.           1. Besides carrying food all over the body, what           other work does the blood do?           2. Why does the blood in the veins look blue?           3. Where is the blood made pure and red again?           4. Where is it sent, from the lungs?           5. What must the lungs have in order to do this

make new muscles as fast as possible. Running, coasting, games of ball, and all brisk play and work, help to make strong muscles. Idle habits make weak muscles. So idleness is an enemy to the muscles. There is another enemy to the muscles about which I must tell you. WHAT ALCOHOL WILL DO TO THE MUSCLES. Muscles are lean meat. Fat meat could not work your joints for you as the muscles do. Alcohol often changes a part of the muscles to fat, and so takes away a part of their strength. In this way, people often grow very fleshy from drinking beer, because it contains alcohol, as you will soon learn. But they can not work any better on account of having this fat. They are not really any stronger for it. REVIEW QUESTIONS.           1. How are the joints moved?           2. Where are the muscles in your arms, which help           you to move your elbows?           3. Show why joints must have muscles.           4. What do we call the muscles of the lower           animals?           5. What fasten the muscles to the

What is said about cigarettes?           28. What about chewing tobacco?           29. To whom is tobacco a great enemy? Why?           30. What is always true of its use by youth? CHAPTER II. MUSCLES. [Illustration: W]HAT makes the limbs move? You have to take hold of the door to move it back and forth; but you need not take hold of your arm to move that. What makes it move? Sometimes a door or gate is made to shut itself, if you leave it open. This can be done by means of a wide rubber strap, one end of which is fastened to the frame of the door near the hinge, and the other end to the door, out near its edge. When we push open the door, the rubber strap is stretched; but as soon as we have passed through, the strap tightens, draws the door back, and shuts it. If you stretch out your right arm, and clasp the upper part tightly with your left hand, then work the elbow joint strongly back and forth, you can feel something under your hand draw up, and then lengthen out again, each time you bend the joint. What you feel, is a muscle (m[)u]s'sl), and it works your joints very much as the rubber

the water in the tea-kettle is boiling, what comes out at the nose? Steam. What is steam? You can find out what it is by catching some of it on a cold plate, or tin cover. As soon as it touches any thing cold, it turns into drops of water. When we boil water and turn it into steam, and then turn the steam back into water, we have distilled the water. We say vapor instead of steam, when we talk about the boiling of alcohol. It takes less heat to turn alcohol to vapor than to turn water to steam; so, if we put over the fire some liquid that contains alcohol, and begin to collect the vapor as it rises, we shall get alcohol first, and then water. But the alcohol will not be pure alcohol; it will be part water, because it is so ready to mix with water that it has to be distilled many times to be pure. But each time it is distilled, it will become stronger, because there is a little more alcohol and a little less water. In this way, brandy, rum, whiskey, and gin are distilled, from wine, cider, and the liquors which have been made from corn, rye, or barley. The cider, wine, and beer had but little alcohol in them. The brandy, rum, whiskey, and gin are nearly one-half alcohol. A glass of strong liquor which has been made by distilling, will injure any one more,

It then leaves with each part, just what it needs. THE BLOOD AND THE BRAIN. As the brain has so much work to attend to, it must have very pure, good blood sent to it, to keep it strong. Good blood is made from good food. It can not be good if it has been poisoned with alcohol or tobacco. We must also remember that the brain needs a great deal of blood. If we take alcohol into our blood, much of it goes to the brain. There it affects the nerves, and makes a man lose control over his actions. EXERCISE. When you run, you can feel your heart beating. It gets an instant of rest between the beats. Good exercise in the fresh air makes the heart work well and warms the body better than a fire could do. DOES ALCOHOL DO ANY HARM TO THE HEART? Your heart is made of muscle. You know what harm alcohol does to the muscles. Could a fatty heart work as well as a muscular heart? No more than a fatty arm could do the work of a muscular arm. Besides, alcohol makes the heart beat too fast, and so it gets too tired. REVIEW QUESTIONS.           1. Where is the heart placed?           2. Of what is it made?           3. What work does it

grains as well as from fruit. The grain has starch instead of sugar. If the starch in your mother's starch-box at home should be changed into sugar, you would think it a very strange thing. Every year, in the spring-time, many thousand pounds of starch are changed into sugar in a hidden, quiet way, so that most of us think nothing about it. STARCH AND SUGAR. All kinds of grain are full of starch. If you plant them in the ground, where they are kept moist and warm, they begin to sprout and grow, to send little roots down into the earth, and little stems up into the sunshine. These little roots and stems must be fed with sugar; thus, in a wise way, which is too wonderful for you to understand, as soon as the seed begins to sprout, its starch begins to turn into sugar. [Illustration] If you should chew two grains of wheat, one before sprouting and one after, you could tell by the taste that this is true. Barley is a kind of grain from which the brewer makes beer. He must first turn its starch into sugar, so he begins by sprouting his grain. Of course he does not plant it in the ground, because it would need to be quickly dug up again. He keeps it warm and moist in a place where he can watch it, and stop the sprouting just in time to save the sugar, before it is used to feed the root

communities.summary:
1. **Title**: Effects of Alcohol Consumption
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the negative effects of alcohol consumption on the human body. Alcohol is formed through the fermentation of sugar in fruit juices, such as grape and apple, and can be found in drinks like wine and cider. Consuming alcohol can lead to addiction, harm the body and mind, and even cause death. The texts also touch on the importance of a healthy diet and the role of different food groups in maintaining a strong body. Additionally, the dangers of tobacco use and the importance of avoiding harmful substances are mentioned. Overall, the texts emphasize the need for responsible behavior and healthy habits to maintain overall well-being.
3. **Keywords**: Alcohol, Addiction, Health, Nutrition, Tobacco

1. **Health and Nutrition**
2. The provided text chunks discuss the importance of a healthy diet and lifestyle, highlighting the benefits of consuming nutritious food and avoiding harmful substances like alcohol. The chunks also explain how the body works, including the conversion of starch into sugar and the role of the heart. Additionally, they emphasize the negative effects of alcohol on the body and mind, including its impact on strength and overall well-being. The text also touches on the composition of bones and the importance of a balanced diet. Furthermore, it discusses the dangers of alcohol and the benefits of a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Nutrition, Alcohol, Strength, Body

1. **Title**: Health and Body Care
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various aspects of health and body care, including the importance of taking care of one's teeth, the dangers of narcotics and tobacco, and the need to maintain a healthy body temperature. The chunks also touch on the negative effects of alcohol and tobacco on the body and the importance of dressing warmly in cold weather. Additionally, the text highlights the financial costs of tobacco and alcohol, emphasizing that money spent on these substances is wasted and can have negative consequences.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Body Care, Tobacco, Alcohol, Narcotics

1. **Title**: Health and Body Functions
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various aspects of human health and body functions, including the importance of fresh air, the role of the lungs, heart, and skin, and the effects of alcohol on the body. The texts also touch on the importance of proper hygiene, such as airing clothes and beds, and the need to avoid close rooms and impure air. Additionally, the chunks warn about the dangers of alcohol consumption and its impact on the body and mind. Overall, the texts aim to educate readers about the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and avoiding harmful substances.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Body Functions, Alcohol, Hygiene, Respiratory System

1. **Title**: Health and Substance Abuse
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the importance of maintaining good health, particularly during childhood and adolescence. They warn against the dangers of substance abuse, such as tobacco and alcohol, which can have severe and long-lasting effects on the body. The chunks also provide guidance on how to care for various parts of the body, including the eyes, ears, and spine, and emphasize the need for healthy habits and responsible decision-making. The overall theme is one of promoting healthy lifestyles and warning against the risks associated with substance abuse. The text also highlights the importance of self-care and responsible behavior, particularly during childhood and adolescence, in order to maintain good physical and mental health.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Substance Abuse, Tobacco, Alcohol, Wellness

1. **Human Physiology Basics**
2. The provided text chunks discuss fundamental concepts of human physiology, including joints, bones, muscles, nerves, and the effects of substances like alcohol and tobacco on the body. The texts appear to be from an educational book, aiming to teach children about the human body and its functions in a simple and practical manner. The book covers various topics, such as the importance of hygiene, the role of organs, and the need for proper nutrition. The overall goal is to provide children with a basic understanding of human physiology and promote healthy habits.
3. **Keywords**: Human Physiology, Health Education, Hygiene

1. **Human Anatomy Basics**
2. The provided text chunks discuss the fundamental components of the human body, including muscles, bones, and nerves. Muscles are described as lean meat that works joints, similar to a rubber strap working a door hinge. The importance of exercise in strengthening muscles is emphasized, and the negative effects of alcohol and idleness on muscle health are noted. The text also touches on the structure and function of bones, including the spine and joints, and the role of nerves in sending messages throughout the body.
3. **Keywords**: Human Anatomy, Muscles, Bones, Nerves

1. **Title**: Photographic Water Purification
2. **Summary**: The collection of text chunks discusses the importance of using pure water in photography, particularly in the preparation of emulsion and development processes. It highlights the need for distilled water and describes various methods for obtaining and purifying water, including the use of rainwater, filters, and distillation apparatus. The chunks also touch on the topic of black phosphorus and its properties, as well as other unrelated topics such as cider production and bone-black revivification. However, the primary focus is on the purification of water for photographic use.
3. **Keywords**: Water Purification, Photography, Distillation, Rainwater, Filtration

1. **Title**: Industrial Machinery and Processes
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss various industrial machinery and processes, including the use of gas furnaces for baking refractory products, the efficiency of fans, and the operation of engines and soaking pits in steel manufacturing. The chunks also touch on the economic advantages of certain processes, such as the soaking pit system, and the properties of metals, including steel, when subjected to different treatments like tempering by compression. The discussions are technical and focused on the practical applications of these machines and processes. The text also mentions the importance of considering factors like fuel cost, maintenance, and efficiency when selecting and operating industrial equipment.
3. **Keywords**: Industrial Machinery, Steel Manufacturing, Gas Furnaces, Engine Efficiency, Tempering Processes

1. **Title**: Ancient Roman Love and Poetry
2. **Summary**: The collection of text chunks revolves around ancient Roman poetry, love, and relationships. The writings appear to be excerpts from the works of Roman poets, such as Ovid and Propertius, and discuss themes of love, beauty, and the role of poetry in expressing emotions. The texts also touch on the social norms and customs of ancient Rome, including the use of cosmetics and the value placed on physical appearance. The poems often express longing and desire, as well as the pain of unrequited love. The use of mythological references and classical allusions adds to the richness and depth of the poetry.
3. **Keywords**: Ancient Roman Poetry, Love, Beauty, Mythology, Classical Allusions
